conclusion: We have an ideal gas that goes through a series of states: from A to B to C, and we're given the pressure and volume values at each point. The temperature at state A is 27°C, and we need to find the temperature at state C.
The x-axis is volume (V) in units of \( \times 10^{-3} \) m³, and the y-axis is pressure (p) in units of \( \times 10^{5} \) Pa. There are points A, B, and C plotted on this graph.
Each square is 1 unit in both pressure and volume.
At point A: V_A = 6 \( \times 10^{-3} \) m³, P_A = 1 \( \times 10^{5} \) Pa
At point B: V_B = 6 \( \times 10^{-3} \) m³, P_B = 2 \( \times 10^{5} \) Pa
At point C: V_C = 3 \( \times 10^{-3} \) m³, P_C = 3 \( \times 10^{5} \) Pa
From A to B: Volume stays constant at 6 \( \times 10^{-3} \) m³, pressure increases from 1 to 2 \( \times 10^{5} \) Pa
From B to C: Pressure increases from 2 to 3 \( \times 10^{5} \) Pa, and volume decreases from 6 to 3 \( \times 10^{-3} \) m³
A: (6, 1), B: (6, 2), C: (3, 3) in units of \( \times 10^{-3} \) m³ and \( \times 10^{5} \) Pa
Given that it's an ideal gas, we can use the ideal gas law: PV = nRT. Since the mass of the gas is constant, n (moles) is also constant.
Convert Celsius to Kelvin: T_A = 300 K

premise: We have two unknowns: T_B and T_C. But we have two processes: A to B and B to C.
conclusion: Identify two processes to find T_B and T_C.

premise: From A to B: V_A = V_B = 6 \( \times 10^{-3} \) m³, P_A = 1 \( \times 10^{5} \) Pa, P_B = 2 \( \times 10^{5} \) Pa, T_A = 300 K
conclusion: Since volume is constant, use Charles' law: P ∝ T when V is constant.
